keyTakeAways: A federal judge in Chicago, US District Judge Sara Ellis, issued a sweeping order restricting ICE and CBP agents’ use of force, requiring body-worn cameras, and mandating warnings before deploying tear gas or pepper balls during protests.

Federal officials, including Deputy Incident Commander Kyle Harvick and ICE Deputy Field Office Director Shawn Byers, testified in court, asserting compliance with the judge’s orders, though the judge expressed serious concerns about non-compliance, particularly regarding deployment of tear gas without warning.

The judge initially demanded that Russell Hott, the interim head of ICE’s Chicago field office, appear to explain reports of tear gas use without prior warning, but he left the city to return to Washington, DC, prompting the administration to offer alternative officials.
Judge Ellis emphasized that she will allow Hott and CBP chief patrol agent Gregory Bovino to be deposed later, citing their authority and position during the protests.

Protests at the Broadview ICE facility continued through the weekend, with over 100 demonstrators gathering and 15 arrests made each day, indicating ongoing public resistance to immigration enforcement actions.

The Trump administration denied media reports of tear gas deployment without warning, claiming the reports were selectively edited and not verified, while the judge expressed skepticism about the government’s transparency.
Judge Ellis stressed that body-worn cameras are critical for documenting events before force is used, and that failure to comply undermines public trust and judicial oversight.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A federal judge in Chicago, US District Judge Sara Ellis, is demanding accountability from federal officials over allegations that agents from Customs and Border Protection (CBP) and Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) violated her order to de-escalate protest actions during Operation Midway Blitz, a recent crackdown in Chicagoland that resulted in over 1,000 arrests. The judge expressed serious concerns that tear gas and pepper balls were deployed without warning, and has mandated that all agents wear body-worn cameras to document such events. Despite officials, including CBP Deputy Incident Commander Kyle Harvick and ICE Deputy Field Office Director Shawn Byers, claiming compliance, the judge remains unsatisfied, particularly due to the absence of Russell Hott, the former interim ICE Chicago field office head, who left the city. The judge will allow Hott and CBP chief patrol agent Gregory Bovino to be deposed later for testimony. Protests at the Broadview ICE facility have continued, with over 100 demonstrators and multiple arrests, showing sustained public resistance. The Trump administration has denied reports of tear gas use without warning, citing media bias, but the judge insists on transparency and accountability to ensure public trust and enforce the law.
title: Federal officials try to reassure judge they’re following her orders to tone down and record Chicagoland protest actions
